newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Philippines poll doubts prevent rating upgrade -S&P.
newsitem.headline: Philippines poll doubts prevent rating upgrade -S&P.

text.p: The Philippines' political outlook is a key uncertainty holding back another credit rating upgrade, a top official with Standard & Poor's Corp said.
David Beers, managing director of S&P's sovereign rating division, said with the line-up of candidates for the 1998 presidential elections undecided, another upgrade was unlikely.
"That's a key uncertainty still holding back another rating upgrade," Beers told Reuters Financial Television (RFTV) in Sydney.
S&P upgraded the Philippines' long-term foreign currency debt to BB-plus from BB in February.
"The rating can definitely move higher," Beers said.
"If it does, it will be if the government is able through the next presidential election to persist with the current fiscal strategy."
"We're still waiting to get a little more insight into who the main presidential candidates are going to be and what their policies are going to be," he said.
So far, a dozen politicians have expressed interest in the Philippines presidency, which will be contested in a poll in June, 1998.
These include five senior members of the administration of President Fidel Ramos, who is constitutionally barred from seeking re-election.
